35. equitum turmae: turma is the term regularly used fora division of Roman cavalry. It is used also, however, as a general term for the cavalry of other nations, andis to be understood here of the Caledonians. Agricola's cavalry, consisting of auxiliarios, is spoken of in the next chapter as alae, the regular expression for

auxiliary cavalry.

22. 2. recentem terrorem, ete: the war-chariots at first caused. some confusion among the assaulting party (the Romans), but soon became useless on the hilly ground, and mixed in with the thick ranks of their own countrymen3 hostium must, from Tacitus* point of view, be the Caledoniam.-

4. minime equestris: the ground not being suited to horses, this battle of the war-chariots, which would properly be ranked with cavalry engagements‚ became minime equestris. The same ex· pression‚ minime equestris more pugnae, is used by Livy (xxii. 47) with reference to the battle of Cannae, where, as here, the horse

. became useless from the closeness of the action and the nature of

the ground.

ς. aegre olivo astantes: the manuscripts read egradlu aut stante; manifestly corrupt. Kritz reads ellvo instantes; Halm and Draeger, adstantes. lt will be noted that in the round hand of the manuscripts cliv could be easily mistaken for diu This ap· pears to refer to the Caledonians3 while the following indicative clause, ao saepe ...incursabant, describes both parties. ln this difficult passage, Kritz (following Wex) reads aequa nostris for equestres of the manuscripts, and instantes for aut stante, making the confusion refer to the Romans. lt is evident‚ however, from the following chapter, circumire terga vincentium, that the Romans were successful so far, and were making their way trium- phantly up the hill. The events of the battle had been as follows: first, the skirmishing eminus; next, the assault made by the Bata· vians and Tungrians; third, the joining of the war-chariots in the battle. after the cavalry had been ronted (Interim . . . haerebant). Then follows a description of the mixed nature of the battle (mini- meque . . . impellerentur), and the confusion caused by the frightened horses (ao saepe ...incursabanty
